title: Ross: A Networked- Epidemiology WebApp

author: Madhav Marathe, Network Dynamics and Simulation Science Laboratory, Virginia Bioinformatics Institute, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

segmentation: So first of all, after a lot of deliberations with my colleagues or the last few.
Hours, at least for this talk, I've decided to change the name of our system.
For obvious reasons I just couldn't deal with saying that over and over again, so I'll call it Ross.
I think it's a reasonably appropriate name.
It is the smallest edit distance with the previous name.
And it's also a tribute to Ronald Ross, who is the with the Pioneer in mathematical modeling for epidemics.
Anne was largely responsible for eliminating or eradicating malaria from the Western world, so the work is joint work with Richard Beckman, Key Bissett.
Chan, Bryan Lewis and Paula Straits.
And we're all at Virginia Tech in the Virginia Biometrics Institute and the Computer science Department.
So I think you all don't need much of an introduction anymore on epidemics, but Even so, let me at least try and reiterate.
What the issues about are about?
Mix are large scale outbreaks of infectious diseases and pandemics are such outbreaks when they happen at a global scale and the Ebola outbreak.
Right now that is ongoing in Africa, is actually a grim reminder of the havoc that such such an event plays in today's social, economic and health.
Issues of our society and even after so many years, while we have made significant progress in controlling pandemics, the last one was a 2009 pandemic which was relatively minor compared to the.
Earlier one.
We still have a long way to go in terms of trying to control such events I've taken.

Information from the New York Times website and the website is given here because I thought it really nicely articulated the kinds of questions folks are interested in, especially from a layman's standpoint, and the article actually talks about timeline, the areas that the place is getting hit with for Ebola, and they ask specific questions right?
They ask questions such as how many people have been infected.
Where is outbreak, where it start?
How did it start?
Where is it likely to go?
How condition contagious is it?
Will it come to US?
So these are the standard questions an epidemiologist is likely to ask when trying to deal with with infectious diseases.
An hope is that we can try and build computational environments that try and support a decision maker when he or she tries to address these questions for the policy folks.
So what we have done is build.
Assist.
Ross, that is a web based tool.
It's a pervasive app to support what would call appear real time epidemic science.
So the work actually really evolved over last.
I would say 11 years or so we start building this first version of the tool in 2006 and I'll tell you a little bit more about it when I discuss the case studies.
But the basic idea that became clearer after we did a lot of modeling work early on was that.
There is no way that we can deploy such tools.

In the hands of policy, makers are analyst without making them easy to use, so a lot of our early work was trying to build models and we're very happy a scientist felt good about it, but we simply did not have any sense of market penetration.
If you want to call our market's policy folks, right, they just did not want to become computer scientist, so we realize it took the hard and bitter pill to swallow.
But we felt that the only way we can reach out to these folks, and they're really important because they are the ones who finally end up using these tools.
We need to make systems that make these tools easily and seamlessly accessible, so that's been the goal here and I will try and show you a little bit about it.
About the tool.
If the wireless holds up, it's always dangerous to try and do real time demos in this meetings.
So what's real time?
Epidemic science?
There is a very nice article in 2009 when the H1N1 pandemic was unfolding by Harvey and Weinberg.
Weinberg, Feinberg, and Harry?
Sorry Feinberg and Harvey Fineberg used to be the president of AAA S then, and they really tried and articulated the role of modeling to support epidemic science.
And they talked about five different issues that.
They felt people need to understand and deal with during during the course of an outbreak.

I've also picked up similar points from a paper by Mark Lipschitz and his colleagues and also by Neil Ferguson and his colleagues where they talk about the kinds of things that modeling could help in supporting pandemic planning.
So before an epidemic you can try and answer questions like you determine the intervention that required the feasibility of containment, the optimal size of stockpile.
Usually for pandemics which are emerging, you do not have a stockpile ready.
You saw that nature and one pandemic case, and the best use of pharmaceutical.

Once a pandemic begins and this is non trivial question, you have very limited supply and you need to assign them to the populations in a way that you think can best control it, and a simple issue that comes around in place like D or in another computer.
Science conferences everybody's interest in optimal allocation.
The problem with such.

Optimal allocation size that they have no implementable viewpoint and we heard about such a talk today to interpret ability of allocation scheme is very, very important, so I cannot say pick people with which are you know particular set of attributes that we cannot even measure in the society.

So these are the kinds of questions that tools like this need to answer and Ross attempts to do that during the course of an epidemic or pandemic, it tries to assess where the disease is going in terms of population level effects.
It tries to assess the impact of the interventions and essentially uses this system like this for situation assessment.
What are the features so the system is set is designed primarily so that analysts are subject matter expert can use it in a seamless manner without having to worry about all the complicated models.
Although the models are fairly transparent, they know it.
They know what the models are, they know the description of it, but they don't have to deal with it on a day-to-day basis.
So the system allows you to design an experiment.
The front end was designed with care.
We have statisticians in the group.
Dick Beckman is one of them.
And it was becoming very clear that if you want to set up a planning case scenario where you want to understand the effects of interventions, then effectively by.
Asking the user to fill out these boxes on the web.

You are essentially guiding or queuing the user to set up a factorial or sparse design OK, and the reason you want to do it is you want to have a fair amount of statistical power to the results that you finally are going to display.
Now of course very quickly this design becomes very large an the system gives cues to the user to try, and an sparsified the design in the amount of time that is available.
The system gives the user choice of various social contact networks that we have built in the group over the last.
15 years or so, these are synthetic networks and the span urban regions.
Right now every urban region the US is covered.
The entire population of US is available in form regions 500 or so cities, and we're starting to extend this outside the country as well.
We have now gotten synthetic networks built out for UK parts in India.
Parts of it were starting to build at in America and also doing places such as this trial and other parts in Mideast.
So that's a kind of network that you want to deal with.
There are multiple forms of disease models that we can.
We can have representations for and then real world intervention, so I'll go through it in some more detail later on.
The point being that it's really an end to end and comprehensive system.
You can change a number of different attributes and you want this to be happening in a fairly seamless manner.
It's also interactive system, so you can actually make some changes, store it, come back, re run it again, which with a few changes.
So from an architecture standpoint, it's the way we've done it so far at least, and we starting to feel a little bit of a pain in terms of scaling up, but it's a blackboard style architect.
So the web app is hooked to a digital through a blackboard to digital library back, but also hooks you to the models and also through the computing resources.
Why is this important?
Well, we wanted the system to be somewhat extensible, so when we started the work we were we were in charge of just one cluster that we have in our group.
We since have now gathered four different clusters and these clusters really help out in terms of doing real time simulation studies.
So given that.
5 minutes I'll quickly move there.
Basically deal with network systems, so not Cody based models.
That is quite common in Epidemiology.
Otherwise, we can deal with very large networks.
The networks have Chicago network, for instance is 8 million individuals in New York.
Network has 16 millions in synthetic individuals.
And this can be handled fairly seamlessly.
Different modeling environments or simulations at the back end.
These are all high performance computing based systems, one of them which is, I think, worth highlighting is in a tool called epidemics.
It was published in Supercomputing and IP DPS last year and it has been the first system to scale to three and 50,000 cores and blue waters and the results can be seen in the paper.
Can support complex interventions.
This is actually very important.
It turns out that much of the work that epidemiologists are doing is to try out interventions or ways to control their policies essentially and then finally diseases.
Represented using a finite state machines, there automata is best represented as a time transition system, and it's a probabilistic one.
It's a big data problem.
I will skip through this given it is given a 5 minute.
Running you can hypothesize the questions, predict, decide, visualize, model them.
The dashboard itself has ways to filter the results.
You can search for past runs.
You can look at the execution status.
You can look at the history of the sessions.
And on and on.

I let me give you a few case studies that motivated this because I think you'll find it of interest and one of the reviewers said that we should highlight this aspect of the system when we got the reviews back.
And so I decided to do that.
So the system did not get built in isolation.
In fact, we stumbled a whole lot early on and that's the reason I want to point it out.
It looks very nice now, but it was not the way it was.
Five six years back we started building the front end back in 2006 when we did a pandemic influenza planning study along with.
And a nice Midas group.

And it led to a interesting PNS paper until who is here is a call through that paper can lead to a strategy called a targeted layer containment, and this is included in the national Pandemic Influenza Plan.
So effectively each case study comes as a question that is raised by a policymaker, to us.
We do the studies, either alone or with them, and then use that to refine the system, and that's how the system gets involved when the H1N1 pandemic came around.

This was actually the first time we were able to hand over the tool to our colleagues at DHS and DoD to use it, and this was run in a real time cycle and real time here doesn't mean it runs as fast as in one second, but within the decision making cycle.
So you get the tool they set up the designs in the afternoon or evening.
The guard results late night.
They took the results back to the decision making table next day.
Most recent use of this is for supporting a senior level exercise which is a tabletop exercise where people would study what if scenarios.
If you want to planning and we're starting to.
Actually, we've been asked to support the Ebola planning exercise as well by the DoD and DHS.
Groups that is right now doing it.
It's very hard.
It's hard, almost always in a situation like this because you have very little information from the ground.
So there's a movie that I want to play, but.
And skip so.
This tool, Ross is a part of a larger suite of tools.
We call it a cyber ecosystem.
It's called SIM demics.
It is got Ross but also got a forecasting tool called flu Caster in it.
It's also got another tool called My Four site which allows.
Multiple forecasts to be then voted to be selected.
Because we found out that these forecasts typically need not give you the best outcomes, so you need individual humans in the loop to do the analysis.
There is a tool called Sivs Synthetic Information Visualizer which can look at the Social Contact Network.
And finally there's a tool called Happy Ways, which allows you to visual analytics with the system.
So as we start building this, we realize that there are many, many different tools that have to be put together to support a real realistic case study.
The demo here and, but I'll skip in the interest of time.
Thank you very much.
